description: From Middle English levene. Spellings in Middle English and Early Modern English include leven, levin, levyn, leiven, and leyven. The earlier etymology is less clear. It is thought to be related to Gothic ğŒ»ğŒ°ğŒ¿ğŒ·ğŒ¼ğŒ¿ğŒ½ğŒ¹ (lauhmuni) (which see for some more), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *lewk- (â€œbright, to shineâ€). Possibly a regular reflex, possibly North Germanic loan, or possibly from a lost substrate.

entries.meaning: (archaic, poetic) Lightning; a bolt of lightning; also, a bright flame or light.
examples: His soul was like the night around us now, dark, and sultry, and silent, but lighted up by the red levin of wrath and torn by the bellowings of thunder-passion.
